newsitem.title: RUSSIA: NATO's Solana in Moscow for next round of talks.
newsitem.headline: NATO's Solana in Moscow for next round of talks.

text.p: NATO Secretary-General Javier Solana arrived in Moscow on Sunday with pressure growing for progress on the thorny subject of the alliance's expansion, before next week's U.S.-Russia summit.
Solana, who leaves on Monday for a tour of Central Asian states, immediately went into talks with Russian Foreign Minister Yevgeny Primakov, the NATO office in Moscow said.

Moscow and NATO are locked in a bitter row over the plans by the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation to invite in new members at a July summit in Madrid. Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic are favourites to be the first.
But both sides have indicated recently a compromise is possible and German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel was quoted on Sunday as saying that more progress had been made than was generally accepted.
"The matter is now under way," Welt am Sonntag newspaper reported him as saying.

Senior NATO and Russian aides have been in Moscow this week preparing the ground for Sunday's meeting after Primakov, a former Russian spy-master, handed over several draft texts on different aspects of a deal in Brussels two weeks ago.

NATO sources say they expect that during the Solana-Primakov meeting, the third this year, they would move to more substantive issues ahead of a summit in Helsinki on March 20 between Presidents Bill Clinton and Boris Yeltsin.
Primakov adopted a flexible tone in a speech on Friday. "We have been and are against the expansion. We are not going to change our position, because NATO's expansion damages us," he said.

"At the same time we do not have a veto right, and of course we will never repeat what happened in 1968 in Czechoslovakia," he said, referring to the Soviet invasion to halt political liberalisation in its former ally.

What Moscow now sought, he said, was a document from NATO that would help guarantee its security. "We want that the essence of this document would be non-advancement of NATO's military infrastructure to our territory," he added.
Diplomats at NATO headquarters in Brussels say the two sides are working on such a document but differences remain.
"There are now two draft texts -- one by Moscow, one by NATO. These two could be merged into a single one, though there would still be many brackets," one alliance source said.

Yeltsin's return to active work after eight months of illness means the West may finally get a decisive response from Moscow. Yet in his annual policy address on Thursday, the Russian president took a hard line against NATO.
"NATO expansion can become a fateful decision which will cost the peoples of Europe very dear," he said, adding that there could be no security system in Europe without Russia.
At a news conference on Friday Clinton voiced hope for progress during his two-day meeting with Yeltsin, but said he expected to face tough issues.

"I expect that the Helsinki meeting will be positive," he said. "But you should understand that this is a tough debate and that they have reasons in their own psyche and circumstances that make it a difficult one."
Clinton added that NATO wanted "a special relationship with Russia and does not rule out even Russian membership in a common security alliance".
Primakov will visit the United States from March 15 to 17 for talks ahead of the Clinton-Yeltsin summit.
